title: Front Fork - Assembly

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Warning - Suspension - Front forks have precision machined parts
The front forks comprise of many precision machined parts.
Total cleanliness must be observed at all times and assembly must take place in a dirt/dust-free environment.
Dirt ingress may cause damage to the fork parts, leading to incorrect operation, instability, loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Front Fork Assembly CB7; CN7, CS7; CE7
Fork Seal and Bearing Bush Installation
Secure the fork outer tube and damper assembly in
Apply a smear of fork oil to the bushes and new seals.
Position the seals and bushes to the fork inner tube as noted during removal. Make sure that the oil seal (item 3) is positioned with the text end facing the circlip (item 2). Use a new circlip.
Using a suitable tool, fit the upper bush to the fork inner tube.
Position the inner tube assembly to the outer. Make sure that the oil and dust seal lips do not become damaged.
to drive the lower bush, washer and oil seal into position. Make sure that the circlip groove is fully visible.
Install a new circlip to retain the oil seal.

body.name: Fork dust seal and circlip - ccuv_6

body.body: Position the dust seal to the outer tube.
with hand pressure only, to press the dust seal into position in the outer tube.
It is much easier to torque the top cap when the fork has been refitted.
Fork Spring and Top Cap Installation
Position the fork assembly as for compression of the fork spring during strip down.
Refit the fork spring spacer, spring, nylon spacer and the bump rubber.

body.name: Front fork spring cap spacer bump rubber

body.body: to the threads of the damper rod and pull the damper upwards.

If removed, the damping rod locknut must be fitted with the flat face facing to the top of the fork. The slightly tapered face must face the fork spring. Incorrect orientation may lead to a loosening of the locknut.
Turn the damper rod locknut until the length of threads to the end of the rod is equal to the length measured during disassembly.

While re-compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
as previously described. Compress the fork spring and refit the spring holder.
Inspect the O-ring for the top cap for any damage, replace if necessary.
Carefully install the top cap and rebound adjuster rod into the damper rod. Slowly turn the cap until it touches the locknut.
Hold the top cap while tightening the damper rod locknut to

While compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
Recompress the spring to remove the spring holder.
Lubricate the O-ring on the top cap with a smear of fork oil then screw the top cap into the outer tube. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
) but do not fully tighten the top yoke clamp fixings at this stage.
Tighten the top yoke clamp fixings to

Fork Spring and Top Cap Installation
Position the fork assembly as for compression of the fork spring during strip down.
Refit the fork spring spacer, spring, nylon spacer and the bump rubber.
